sect1.title: A History of GTK+
sect1.para: GTK+ was originally developed for GIMP, the GNU Image Manipulation Program. GTK+ stands for the GIMP Tool Kit. GTK+ has grown from these beginnings and is now used as a central part of Gnome, the GNU Projects desktop environment. GTK+ has also been ported to BeOS and Win32, making it the perfect choice to use as the basis for a PHP extension, keeping PHP as cross-platform as possible and allowing the creation of windowed applications in PHP for Linux, BeOS and Windows.

sect1.title: What does GTK+ do?
sect1.simpara: GTK+ is a set of libraries written in C to create graphical user interfaces. It has an object oriented architecture developed in three libraries:

listitem.simpara: provides various tools for use when programming with GTK+.
abstracts the low-level window drawing functions.
provides a set of widgets for use when creating your GUI.
